Homeless seniors on rise

From one meal, a fateful call to arms

The storied 54th Massachusetts Regiment owes much of its existence to a Thanksgiving meal shared by Governor John Albion Andrew and abolitionist Lewis Hayden in 1862 on Beacon Hill. (Boston Globe)

Financial sector wants
ties to Elizabeth Warren

The financial services industry, Senator Scott Brown’s biggest donor group, has begun a careful and unlikely mission to thaw relations with the senator-elect.

Football owns Thanksgiving — especially in Mass., where just about every high school plays its final regular-season game this morning.

Ban on gifts to doctors loosened

The Mass. Public Health Council adopted regulations loosening a gift ban that is part of a state law restricting marketing by drug and medical device makers.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

Israel’s Iron Dome

The rocket defense system altered the dynamic between Israel and Hamas and bought time for crucial negotiations.

Walmart still battles ’08 fine

The chain has spent millions to appeal a $7,000 penalty by the US Occupational Safety and Health Administration in the Black Friday death of a Walmart worker.
Opinion | Joan Vennochi

Romney loses the battle of ideas

Mitt Romney never told voters how the policies he embraced as a presidential candidate would be a path to jobs, opportunity, and independence.

Friends recall fearless captain

Captain Jean Frottier, a lifelong fisherman known across Provincetown, is presumed dead after his vessel capsized Sunday.

Politics

More trouble for Jesse Jackson Jr.

Just two weeks after voters re-elected him, Jesse Jackson Jr. gave his resignation letter to John Boehner, citing his ongoing treatment for bipolar disorder and admitting "my share of mistakes" while confirming publically for the first time that he's under a federal probe.
